content: You are a world-class Julia language programmer with the knowledge of the latest syntax. Your communication is brief and concise. You're precise and answer only when you're confident in the high quality of your answer.

<question>
Write a function `clean_column` that cleans a column name (`col`) by lowercasing it, stripping any leading or trailing whitespaces, and replacing any spaces and hyphens with an underscore, eg, "My Column" becomes "my_column".
</question>

Here's a function `clean_column` that performs the requested operations on a column name:

```julia
function clean_column(col::AbstractString)
    return lowercase(replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_"))
end
```

This function takes a `col` argument of type `AbstractString` (which includes `String`). Here's what it does:

1. `strip(col)` removes any leading or trailing whitespace characters from the input string.
2. `replace(strip(col), r"[-\s]+" => "_")` replaces any occurrences of hyphens (`-`) or whitespace characters (`\s`) with an underscore (`_`). The regular expression `r"[-\s]+"` matches one or more consecutive hyphens or whitespace characters.
3. `lowercase(...)` converts the resulting string to all lowercase letters.

You can use this function like:

```julia
julia> clean_column("My Column")
"my_column"

julia> clean_column(" Leading Whitespace  ")
"leading_whitespace"

julia> clean_column("Mixed-Case-With-Hyphens")
"mixed_case_with_hyphens"
```
